The example from Steven Johnson's book that talks about books being linear and their content not interactive is pretty funny. Of course, this book is from 2006 so maybe he couldn't have anticipated what the internet would become. He says that the author controls the narrative and it is dangerous because the reader is not in control, but when you read a book the text does not change from one reader to the other one. So it would be harder for the author to control big masses, when in the case of let's say Facebook the content is tailored to the individual, so if Facebook wants to pursue someone to believe in something they can use an individual approach. Thanks to an abundance of data on users and computational power to analyze this data the problem of mass control becomes feasible. So books are definitely not a better medium for mass control compared to the internet.

The web started out as a source of textual information. And it was good. Websites were all like Wikipedia. I was a voracious reader, and preferred reading to videos as a way of learning (plus videos used to cost money). But in the last decade Youtube has evolved so well that I’ve stopped reading. I expect schools might stop teaching kids how to read in a few generations, because video or audio is just as good, probably significantly better. People with dislexia or learning disabilities are already benefitting from video on demand like YouTube.

When the internet was new, we could learn subjects including computers and history. Now we can learn anything in minutes by watching a very specific video, like how to fix a Samsung refrigerator. Video has already surpassed literature.

That bit about reading being passive isn't so good, but it is a conceit that's cute for a moment or two.  Reading requires visualization and the involvement of other senses, and what you get out of much of it depends who you are.  People with different levels of intellect will get different results.  So will someone who reads about how a flower smells and remembers it instead of not sharing the sense impression the author attempts to convey.  Have a half dozen people read a poem and see how many different impressions you get, from appreciation to understanding, and on many different levels.  Try to read a book after seeing the movie and not picture the hero with the actor's face.  Try to read a book with politics you disagree with and feel unaffected.  You create your experience when reading because the process of translating words to thought and imagery is quite active, even though directed.  Activity and direction are not opposites.  Heck, a trip on horseback may be directed, but the experience of it differs wildly depending on the rider.  You are taken someplace, but what you see is yours.

Simply anything and everything that can be answered, is answered or researched can be found simply by typing in a question.

Having the internet at home in the late 90's/early 00's was magical. As a child you felt like you had a key to a mystical city that not a lot of people had. Websites were slow, flash animations ruled supreme, basic HTML was the norm. I still remember going on Youtube in 2005 and being blown away by how smoothly and quickly I could watch a video online with it's player, when only a few years beforehand I waited 15-30 minutes to able to watch a 45 second video in Quicktime without it stopping.

As time on goes on the internet resonates with and accommodates more people of all ages and it's lost that magic. It's in your pocket now and it's taken for granted. I'll never forget how magical the internet once was

To say that old sci-fi stories inspired current technology is probably incorrect. Did we design airplanes based on our inspiration of birds? No. When you look at all the ways airplane wings deviate from bird wings you realize they are different pieces of technology. The reason they have similar shape is not because one is trying to mimic the other but rather because the mechanical laws of the universe dictate such designs. We would expect alien creatures on another planet (that fly) to develop very similar shapes and methods of movement. They are constrained by the laws of ohysics in the same way the bird, plane, and alien are.
The point is that sci-fi designs become real in the future not because those inventors were copying old ideas but rather because in the 'old' days the people writing the stories (or films) were looking forward with a good sense of design creativity. Why does the old sci-fi spacesuit look like a can on the guys head? Because he needs a can on his head to survive in the vacuum of space. Why do present spacesuits look similar? Because you need a can on your head to survive in outer space.

As a writer, I'd argue that books & other printed literature are better for going into deep subject matter & explaining. character motivations & thought processes; while interactive video media is better at conveying a fuller spectrum of personal communication. Read a hand written letter & you can get some of the authors personality thru word choice & handwriting; read printed matter, & the author's down to sentence structure, paragraph. construction. & word choice. Blogs & videos are the best at communicating thru intonation,  gesture & expression, plus unplanned spontaneity. Communication of ideas needs both mediums: printed matter is more easily recalled, since you can go back & reread; while audio/visual is more entertaining & stimulating.

I have a question and I need the internet experts here to give me their advice.

I've been wanting to go on the deep web for a while now but I'm hesitating cause I don't know much about it and I'm not a computer expert.

Here's my plan: I'm gonna buy an old, cheap, piece of shit laptop only for this reason. I'll make sure not to out ANY information on that laptop. I won't log into my email, Facebook, or any website that can be linked to me. I'll even pay cash when I buy it. I won't use a credit card, etc. I'll only use this laptop to go on the deep web, and nothing else. And when I do it, I won't use my home wifi. I'll just use a public network.

I'll download TOR and go on the deep web. I'm just doing this out of curiosity. I wanna see what goes on there.

What do you guys think? Is that a good plan? Or am I still running the risk of getting hacked and getting my info stolen? Is there anything else that I should worry about?

Notes:
** I won't download anything from the deep web.
** I'll switch off JavaScript
** when I use TOR, I'll use an IP from a foreign country.
** I'll use only public wifi, nothing from home.
** I'll make sure not to go very deep cause I don't want to see something that could scar me for life.

Let me know if there's anything else that I should worry about.

I hope this doesn't make people disregard books completely. books are really important. yes, you do read linearly, and that's what makes reading on paper so much different than online. I read a book by Nick Carr entitled "The Shallows: What the Internet is Doing to Our Brains," and he coins the term of online reading as "F" reading. we read a line, then another. then we read some of the next line, then read even a little less after that. eventually, we're just skimming the text, looking for tidbits of information that are revelant to what we're looking for, maybe even clicking on hypertext that takes us to another text body that expounds on another subject. while the Internet is great for getting general information, fully comprehending and "knowing" something takes a little bit more. it's hard for us to read traditionally now, since we are so used to the fast-paced reading that the online world offers us. but we need to be able to do this offline so we can do what is called "deep reading." this is when you are fully immersed in the text, caught in the twists and turns of the page, usually a narrative. but page text can also be non-narratives. they can be essays, magazine articles, newspapers, journals, etc. and it is this "deep reading" where we comprehend an idea or subject the most, and where we can perhaps formulate our own creative or original thought

I have  a question for you.  If Socrates lived in modern times, would you be that Socrates?  Think about it, Socrates would have used the most efficient way to get his philosophies across, and the Web would be the best way (the internet being the best way to get the information to the most people).  He would use his Socratic method to question everything, kind of how you question many things on your YouTube channel.  Come to think of it, you would be more like Aristotle or Plato, since you are constantly referencing Philosophers before you.  Your YouTube channel would be Aristotle's Lyceum, or Plato's Academy, and we would be your students.  Maybe you could give this idea a bit more thought, thanks.

The internet is actually a collection of routers, switches and servers. The routers process your request to reach a specific server by using certain criteria such as the source and destination IP address, MAC address, and port numbers, and routing them  through routing protocols (mainy BGP when you reach the intenet through a service provider) also internal routing protocols (IGPs) such as EIGRP, OSPF etc. After you are routed to your destination, you request info from a web server, which then processes your requests and routes the info back through "IP PACKETS". The internet boils down to packets routed through service providers to reach specific network devices.

Why are people disliking this?

The fact that using the internet can exercise the brain more so than reading books isn't always a good thing. The calm, thoughtful "deep reading" that comes with being fully engrossed in a book allows us to more carefully focus and store the information into long term memory more efficiently. Frequent use of the internet changes the ways our very brains function, reducing our capacity for concentration without distraction, and emphasizing skimming of content quickly.

I would recommend everybody to check out the book "The Shallows: What the Internet is Doing to our Brains" by Nicholas Carr. He makes a very good case for this, and he even references "Everything Bad is Good for You", in which Steven Johnson states that when compared to using the internet, "reading books chronically understimulates our senses." Carr argues that through the concentrated, linear nature of reading a book, "...allowing us to filter out distractions to quiet the problem-solving functions of the frontal lobes, deep reading becomes a form of deep thinking... When it comes to the firing of our neurons, it's a mistake to assume that more is better."

Before the internet, there were BBSes (bulletin board systems) run by individuals.  The BBSes would connect to each other.  People could chat across the world using this system.  Most BBSes would give you a busy signal because they had only one phone line.  The better BBSes had multiple phone lines.  AOL, GE, Commodore, etc. had the top level BBSes.

Michael, as smart as a guy you are, it's not a good idea to go about browsing the deep web unless you're specifically looking for something. A lot of which is morally reprehensible. The peak of the deep web is haven to hackers and script kiddies, celebrity gossip, research data and government files (wikileaks started here). Anyone who frequents it enough, knows about what lies below that, and not exactly that much farther down. At best, the deep web at its peak is morally sketchy with suicide recordings, gore, low-ball child pornography. Superviruses lurk here as well, like Michelangelo or Blowfish. If you're browsing here, know what you're doing, and have a strong antivirus.

As we go down and require TOR services with more dedication, we approach powerful artificial intelligence, data analysis, company secrets and contacts that you aren't supposed to know as a rank and file citizen. Be warned, at this point, you are dealing with people who are MUCH smarter than you. You may run into the wrong alley if you catch the metaphor.

As we go deeper, we are going into the absolute morally derelict sections of the internet. Things that I won't even discuss in detail in public, but more commonly, assassination networks, weapons trade, hard drugs dealing, human trafficking, SLAVERY, hardcore child pornography, exotic animal trade, poaching, corporate exchanging, multi-billion dollar deals, hard candy, the Silk Road (which has been taken down), the dark network...

Your proxy that you've been using is basically useless at this point. In all honesty, if you are a normal, law abiding citizen, there is no reason why you should be here. Absolutely none. Click on the wrong thing, you could have federal authorities busting down your door, or worse, people that you don't even know. You should be paranoid at finding information.

As you go deeper, and at this point we're deep, we're finding information that you can't even access unless you're the top 1% of computer know-how. AI Superintelligence, the Nephilism courier network, the AI box, even more hardcore pornography (Ariel Castro type, the things here make him look like a small time drug dealer). It's very sketchy in here, and it's expected to go deeper, in what's called the Mariana's Web. What lies here is anyone's guess.


tl;dr Don't go browsing the deep web, you DON'T know what you're getting yourself into. Some people have said on here that you're going to be put in prison immediately, that's not true, but I guarantee you that there is a reason why this is a haven for those who don't want to be tracked.

It is the real deal criminal world on the power on the internet, doing what criminals have always done, and they're smart. Smarter than the vast number of you that's for damn sure. It gives me chills down my spine to even think about that stuff that is going on in the deep web.

Both books and the internet share one thing as far as users are concerned. They both let you experience the thoughts of someone else. You use your own ideas the paint in the missing details. You imagine what a character looks like or how it moves in a book. You predict what your actions will lead to, and use problem solving to travel your path in a game, you share your opinions of videos on youtube, and comment on what you think a person may have meant in the video, but you're following the creator's lead. You're doing what you can in the background, relatively unnoticed. Books and TV, Games, the internet, are all fun and somewhat interactive. But aren't the creators of ALL this material really the ones benefiting their true effects? Doesn't imagining new ideas and bringing them to life stimulate you more than imagining the the author's ideas as described through text, or imagining the future of a series, imagining the outcome of a game? Media is okay for the users, but being the creator is the most stimulating act. The most fulfilling achievement. I love books, games, youtube. But I'd rather make my own worlds. The internet makes that possible for MANY people, that's far more than a book could ever do.

it's funny that the word 'troll' also originally comes from a fishing term 'trawl' which was basically 'trawling new users on the web' by well, trolling them.  The Internet is really an ocean; almost every term we use have some connection with life at sea one way or the other.

I think text based information (e.g., books) requires greater stimulation of the brain's creative faculties since it requires the mind to imagine all the sensory information instead of having it provided directly as images or sounds. Although the internet contains text based information, it is largely driven by multimedia that is more directly stimulating to the senses, thus making the absorption of information a more passive act since it does not require imagination.

Furthermore, the "linearity" or "rigidity" of books requires a sense of discipline, as we have to coerce our ever shortening attention spans into maintaining focus on a particular subject in order to gain depth of knowledge, not breadth.

I have a question i've been thinking about. Are we in the same time period? You could wake up in the middle of the night and have insomnia and stay awake all night, while your friend could have slept and already have been at morning. Sleeping is kind of like a fast forward button. Like one person doesn't sleep at night for 8 hours. They could have experienced the night hour by hour. Another person could sleep for those hours and not have dreamed or been interrupted. Sleeping might have felt like only 5 minutes to them. So are you behind the person in a time period?

The only thing that it does do is make us feel good, but why? And why is it that beginning music  starts with a defined pattern, but can only be perfected by straying away from the pattern and making notes seamless. Even while reading a book, the supposed mandatory linearity with which a presumed 'message' is transferred doesn't exist, once the history is re-assembled by the reader in a process of self-referential elements cued by the text written, but not equal/correspondent or even close to them. A same written story has, to the level of linguistic narrativity, a similar reproduction among the same language, but the inaccessible personal montage, the pictorial elements displayed or triggered are personal referential, so do the 'values' and all other conclusions taken in a semantic level.

This process is also present in absolutely any form of narrativity, even games, for instance, the level of personal (subjective) construction of the narrativity is still predominant. And here, books, delivering nothing but written words leave a wider gap to be filled subjectively by the act of transforming linear narrativity into mental images in correspondence to mental social-historico-contextual models. In Lacanian terms, registers of the external Other are but Registers, always open to refractions and deformations.

Unless this speech still presumes the concreteness of a 'message' as something to be accessed, which is one of the premisses of the rationalism, and had been long proved wrong by psychology and cognitive sciences (to don't say phenomenology also.)

Mr. Stephens:
I have nothing against trying new things, small changes made to content, later measured, to verify increase or decrease brought on by the change. This type thing happens all the time, especially on Youtube, sometimes for the better, often times not, change is then usually taken back or further tweaked until a desired outcome is reached.
I have nothing against the musical talent you have used in recent weeks, I don't think the selections picked have been very fitting to the Vsauce mold. Mr McCoy I'm sure would be better listened to as a stand alone product. Not tossed into the sauce, in an attempt to recreate the ambiance we took for granted a few months back.
Honestly, Vsauce without Jake Chudnow's ambient sounds tying everything together is like having a race car, that when you press the accelerator, instead of an engines roar, you hear a squeaking hamster wheel.
As one of the earliest subscribers, and a faithful follower of all things Vsauce, I'd like to address the issue of Jake Chudnow's audio tracks, and their sudden removal from the channel. The two parts, the channels content, and those music tracks, were a marriage found nowhere else. JC's tracks helped create a feel that so far no replacement you've provided has been able to accomplish. As an unbiased viewer/listener I think the removal of JC's music reduces the whole Vsauce experience, without that feel the channels content is reduced to just one small step ahead of most other science and discovery type channels, that being due to the way Michael draws an audience in veering all different directions from the first stated sentence therefore breaking the monotony other related channels fall victim to. Vsauce seriously needs to consider bringing Jake Chudnow back or possibly dropping background music completely until a more suitable replacement can be had. What I heard this episode was more of a distraction than smooth background fill.
Even if what I have said falls on deaf ears, I will still be watching, learning, filling the gray matter.
Thank you for your time.

comment_text: Damn...this is deep...

Actually there were a global network for DIGITAL communication long before the Internet. Devices called teletypes were constructed on the beginning of 20th century and used for decades to send text messages over long distances, via cable or radio channel. Those messages were fully digital - characters were encoded binary with so called Baudot Code (predecessor of ASCII). Devices itself were electromechanical, not electronic.

ARPANet was created in different purpose - sharing big mainframe's computing power. Few years later microprocessor was invented and any institution could afford cheap and powerful computer, so communication and data transmission became main application of new network.

Oh, and the teletypes? They still were in use - as computer terminals. What do you think, what is the meaning of "TTY" abbreviation, commonly used in Unix system to describe serial port? Did I mention that basis of serial transmission of data was also borrowed from teletype technology? ;)

Where do you guys get that kind of nonsense info from regarding the "deep web" ?

The "deep web" is non indexed content of "common" search engines(bing, google and so on).

If for example I have a telnet, ssh or even common browser readable content or just a server that is accessible public but not indexed, it's part of "the deep" web.



The part you guys are thinking about, is loopholes(stepstones), to closed "internal"/tunnel networks, with own search engines, DNS, rule sets and route distribution(OSPF with BGP).

90% of the time, they are not accessible for public. 

Just don't go to the illegal sites. It's common sense, there is even allot of illegal content/sites that is indexed, but you don't go there anyways, so why is the non-indexed more fun ?

Another point to make about books and the web is that if the web came first, one would have more advanced sources of references. Wikipedia, for instance, would be updated continuously, just like it is today, whereas publishing encyclopaedias, biographies, textbooks, etc. would involve republishing updated editions, given that one cannot simply edit a book like you can a webpage; a more impractical process. If books became the obsession like they were suggested in this video, the majority of people would have piles of outdated information.

If you arent currently aware, The neutrality of the internet is being challenged (I know this is a long paragraph, but seriously read this). Basically they want it to be more like cable networks, where you pay more for access to certain services (Instead of an HBO package it could be a Social Media package where you only have access to Social sites). This would destroy the internet as we know it and would render an extremely uneven playing ground for countries who are new to the internet and smaller internet companies that cant afford to pay more to be connected to users.

"Profits and corporate disfavor of controversial viewpoints or competing services could change both what you can see on the Internet and the quality of your connection." - ACLU.org

It not only affects you, the consumer, but the service providers as well. A service like Youtube or Netflix would most certainly be charged more for connecting to users than their fair share of bandwidth would normally cost.

"In this unregulated environment, the Internet may quickly be sold to the highest bidder, chilling the free speech we now enjoy online" -ACLU

Your brief acknowledgement of net neutrality in the video needs to be emphasized as the laws that protected it are now essentially being thrown by the wayside and ISPs will have the ability to regulate stuff they deem unworthy for their customers, essentially making the choices for us.  They could slow down or even simply refuse anything from being accessed. 

There is stuff on the Deep Web that is very useful but hard to find.  If Net Neutrality goes away, there will be another deeper level than the Deep Web, and it will be known as something like the "Lost Web".  Stuff that can't be accessed by the majority of people because it's not approved by their ISP.  And there will be stuff on the Web that will fall directly into this hole as well. 

Just a heads up for everybody.  Inform yourselves please.
